awd_titl_txt: Novel Graphene-based Label-free Biosensor Array for Smart Health and Drug Discovery
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Koley, Goutam   
Proposal Number: 1606882 

The goal is to develop bio-implantable sensors utilizing the unique material properties of graphene and boron nitride, which would offer much higher sensitivity for detecting concentration of various ions in blood and tissue in real time, enabling prediction of the onset of disease states before their clinical manifestation.  The project activities would integrate research with education and training of high school, undergraduate and graduate students, with significant minority participation. 

The overall goal of the proposed research is to develop novel graphene-based flexible ion-sensitive field effect transistor (ISFET) sensors for the measurement of K+, Ca2+ and Na+ ion concentrations and correlated ion fluxes in cardiomyocytes and glial cells, with the overall objective of developing a new approach for assaying cell membrane ion transport in primary cell culture. The detection of the aforementioned ions is clinically significant as they serve as important bio-markers for onset of myocardial ischemia and epilepsy.  The proposed graphene ISFET sensor array will enable critical understanding of K+, Ca2+ and Na+ membrane transport in glial cells and cardiomyocytes. The approach of ISFET development utilizing the novel properties of boron nitride and graphene addresses several critical issues including: (i) the complicacy, low throughput and cell invasiveness issues of patch clamp and microelectrode array based techniques, and (ii) the low sensitivity and degradation of commercially available Si-based ISFETs. The experimental plan includes growing cells directly on graphene and performing continuous, real-time and label-free measurements of ion fluxes in cardiomyocytes and glial cells.  The measurements acquired are expected to provide electrophysiological properties of primary cells in culture, especially regulatory and drug-induced changes in their electrical properties.  Successful completion would result in the development of useful ISFET sensors for in vivo detection of the onset of myocardial ischemia and epilepsy. As  part of the educational and outreach activities, the PIs would each involve at least one undergraduate and one high school student to work on this project every year focusing strongly on recruiting minority students. The PIs would also integrate research results in a graduate course, and disseminate them through conference participation as well as research websites.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project resulted in the development of novel graphene-based ion-sensitive field effect transistors (ISFETs) for performing continuous, real-time and label-free measurements of K+ ion fluxes in cardiomyocytes and glial cells with applications in smart health, drug discovery and personalized medicine. The development of these devices can significantly expedite drug discovery through well array-based monitoring of cellular ion efflux under application of various test medicinal drugs. Additionally, they can have strong impact on human health since in implanted conditions they can continuously monitor the presence of K+ ions in cardiac tissues and in brain tissues, which is an important precursor bio-marker for cardiac arrest and epilepsy. These ion sensor devices were built by leveraging the ultra-high sensitivity of graphene to adsorbed ions, which selective detection of K+ ion was achieved through a Valinolycin based polymer functionalization layer on the graphene surface.  The final fabricated device demonstrated very high sensitivity of a few micromolar concentration of the K+ ion, while also displaying very high selectivity against other interfering ions such as Na+ and Ca2+.

The project activities have led to significant contributions to the major discipline of electrical engineering, as well as in the related disciplines of Biomedical engineering, Materials Science and Chemistry.  The development of the ISFETs have led to better understanding of graphene based miniaturized ISFETs and their capability for highly sensitive and selective detection of specific ions in physiological solutions used for cell growth studies. A wide array of significant research results were obtained over several years, which resulted in the publication of 9 journal publications, 2 patent applications, 7 conference presentations, and several invited talks.

The project activities also led to very significant technological and educational broader impacts. In terms of technological broader impact, the development of highly sensitive and selective array based ISFET sensor can have strong potential applications in smart health, drug discovery and personalized medicine. The project also resulted in the training of 3 postdoctoral researchers, 3 doctoral students and 5 Master of Science students. Additionally, eight undergraduate students were also trained in this project. The training that the students obtained from this project enabled them to find employment in reputed companies such as Texas Instruments, Micron, Koppers Inc., Schweitzer Engineering Laboratories Inc., Modjoul Inc. and faculty position at the Texas A&M University. The intellectual properties generated from the research has also attracted interest from commercial entities for developing marketable sensor systems. The project also led to the creation of research infrastructure at Clemson university (in terms of specialized materials synthesis and characterization equipment, gas/ion sensor test beds as well as miniaturized multimodal sensor data acquisition system), knowledge base, and expertise in the PI?s lab, which is expected to lead to further application of this very promising technology in a large variety of existing and emerging areas.

 


Last Modified: 08/23/2022
Modified by: Goutam Koley
